z:row.TitlePrimary: On the definition of internal energy in thermostatics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 175 FIFTH AVE, NEW YORK, NY 10010 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Bannatek Press, Madison, WI 53744 USA.; Lodge, AS, Bannatek Press, POB 44133, Madison, WI 53744 USA.
z:row.Abstract: In a very generous review (Jongschaap, 22001) of my latest book, the reviewer disagreed with the following comment on my use of the treatment or Born ( 1921. 1964) and Caratheodory: Moreover, the treatment (as it should be at this stage) is entirely macroscopic, the definitions being so clear that it is not necessary to appeal to molecular concepts as Callen [19601 does" (Lodge 1999, p. 7). The reviewer wrote: "Many readers will consider these starting points for deducing the basic laws and state functions of thermodynamics more difficult than for instance a treatment based upon Callen's (Callen 1985) approach of which the author suggests (p. 7) that an appeal to molecular concepts is needed. This, I think, is not correct; Callen's axioms are purely phenomenological and also acceptable without molecular considerations."

z:row.TitlePrimary: On-line measurement of elasticity and viscosity in flowing polymeric liquids
z:row.Keyword: slit die|on-line rheometry|first normal stress difference|hole pressure|Stressmeter|viscosity|molten polymers|multigrade oil elasticity|high shear rates|SHEAR RATES|POLYISOBUTYLENE|Mechanics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BERLIN 33; C/O SPRINGER-VERLAG, HEIDELBERGER PLATZ 3, 1000 BERLIN 33, GERMANY
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Lodge, AS, BANNATEK CO INC,POB 5472,MADISON,WI 53705.
z:row.Abstract: A new slit-die rheometer (the ''Stressmeter'') for on-line and sample measurement of the viscosity, eta, and the first normal stress difference, N-1, in steady shear flow for molten polymers and other high-viscosity liquids is described. Two liquid-filled transverse slots, located in one die wall near the center station, give pressures P-2 and P-3 from whose difference the wall shear stress a is calculated. In the other die wall at a location opposite the center of the P-2 slot is a flush-mounted transducer, giving a pressure P-t. N-1 is calculated from the hole pressure P* = P-1-P-2. A metering pump, used to measure the flow rate Q, is supplied with melt either from an extruder (on-line mode) or from a pressurized sample cylinder (sample mode). The wall shear rate gamma is calculated from Q and sigma; the Weissenberg-Rabinowitsch correction and a new small-viscous-heating-correction algorithm (affecting sigma) are used. Viscous heating corrections are small; entrance and exit errors are negligible. The instrument is tested by comparing its results with those obtained from cone-plate and capillary rheometers. Measurement ranges extend to sigma = 200 kPa, gamma = 3000 s(-1), and temperature = 250 degrees C.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Polymer-Solutions and Melts - Viscosity, Diffusion, and Elasticity
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WASHINGTON; PO BOX 57136, WASHINGTON, DC 20037-0136
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: LODGE, AS, BANNATEK CO INC,POB 5472,MADISON,WI 53705.
z:row.Abstract: In an empirical attempt to extend the ''rubberlike liquid'' temporary-junction network theory to polymeric liquids whose viscosity eta depends on shear rate gamma, it is assumed that, in steady shear flow, the sample-average strand lifetime [tau] may depend on gamma, and that, for linear polymers of a given molecular weight M, [tau] is inversely proportional to the self-diffusion coefficient D in a liquid at rest. It is assumed that the plateau modulus G(0) may be used to determine the strand concentration v. Literature data for molten polystyrene and for a 15% solution of polystyrene in toluene give approximate superposition of the curves for sigma/G(0) vs gamma/D, where sigma denotes the shear stress; curves for sigma vs gamma differ by a factor of about 10 000. Curves for G(0)(N-1 - N-2)/sigma(2) vs sigma/G(0) are about 100 times closer together than the corresponding curves for (N-1 - N-2)/sigma(2) vs sigma, but do not superpose; this suggests that [tau(2)]/[tau](2) depends on the polymer concentration. N-1 and N-2 denote the first and second normal stress differences.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Viscous Heating Correction for Thermally Developing Flows in Slit Die Viscometry
z:row.Keyword: SLIT DIE VISCOMETER|DEVELOPING THERMAL FIELD|VISCOUS HEATING CORRECTION|FINITE ELEMENT METHOD|Mechanics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: BERLIN 33; C/O SPRINGER-VERLAG, HEIDELBERGER PLATZ 3, 1000 BERLIN 33, GERMANY
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGINE RES CTR,DEPT ENGN MECH,MADISON,WI 53706.; KO, YS, UNIV WISCONSIN,RHEOL RES CTR,ENGN RES BLVD,1500 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: In the thermally developing region, d-pi-yy/dx\y = h varies along the flow direction x, where pi-yy denotes the component of stress normal to the y-plane; y = +/- h at the die walls. A finite element method for two-dimensional Newtonian flow in a parallel slit was used to obtain an equation relating d-pi-yy/dx\y = h and the wall shear stress sigma-w0 at the inlet; isothermal slit walls were used for the calculation and the inlet liquid temperature T0 was assumed to be equal to the wall temperature. For a temperature-viscosity relation eta/eta-0 = [1 + beta(T-T0)]-1, a simple expression [(hd-pi-yy/dx\y = h)/sigma-w0] = 1 - [1 - F(c)(Na)][M(chi) + P(Pr) .Q(Gz-1)] was found to hold over the practical range of parameters involved, where Na, Gz, and Pr denote the Nahme-Griffith number, Graetz number, and Prandtl number; chi is a dimensionless variable which depends on Na and Gz. An order-of-magnitude analysis for momentum and energy equations supports the validity of this expression. The function F(c)(Na) was obtained from an analytical solution for thermally developed flow; F(c)(Na) = 1 for isothermal flow. M(chi), P(Pr), and Q(Gz) were obtained by fitting numerical results with simple equations. The wall shear rate gamma-w0 at the inlet can be calculated from the flow rate Q using the isothermal equation.

z:row.TitlePrimary: The Hole-Pressure Problem
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; WALTON ST JOURNALS DEPT, OXFORD, ENGLAND OX2 6DP
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: PENN STATE UNIV,DEPT MATH,UNIVERSITY PK,PA 16802. UNIV HOUSTON,DEPT MATH,HOUSTON,TX 77204.; LODGE, AS, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGINE & RHEOL RES CTR,1600 JOHNSON ST,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: The steady flow of a Newtonian fluid between two parallel planes separated by a distance h is considered. In one of the planes, there is a slot whose breadth is bh and whose depth is dh. The slot runs transversely to the direction of the fluid motion. The mathematical and experimental problem is to determine the difference between the normal stress acting on the bottom of the slot and that acting on the upper wall above the opening to the slot, a quantity often referred to as the hole pressure. This flow is of considerable practical interest, especially when non-Newtonian materials are employed, and is the basis of a commercial instrument used to help characterize non-Newtonian fluids. The determination of the Newtonian hole pressure is an interesting problem in its own right. A theoretical knowledge of the hole pressure from numerical solutions of the appropriate mathematical problem can provide a very useful way of determining determining that the instrument is, in fact, giving meaningful measurements. The numerical computation of the hole pressure is a reasonably challenging calculation for a Navier-Stokes solver and, being intimately related to a practical flow, provides a nice test calculation against which to evaluate the properties of a new code. In particular, it would appear to provide a more interesting calculation than the familiar driven-cavity flow (which, incidentally, is a limiting case of the hole-pressure calculation). In this paper, some of the properties of the flow are examined, and, on the basis of computations, a standard calculation is proposed, where the hole pressure is determined as a function of the Reynolds number in the special case of a square hole with b = d = 1. Some comparisons are made between different computations of the hole pressure, and comparisons are also given, for the case of extremely deep holes, between computed values of the hole pressure and experimental measurements.

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the definition of internal energy in thermostatics [and reply]
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: The Bannatek Press, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Lodge states that in a very generous review (Jongschaap, 2001) of his latest book, the reviewer disagreed with the following comment on my. use of the treatment of Born (1921, 1964) and Caratheodory: "Moreover, the treatment (as it should be at this stage) is entirely macroscopic, the definitions being so clear that it is not necessary to appeal to molecular concepts as Callen [1960] does" (Lodge 1999, p. 7). The reviewer wrote: "Many readers will consider these starting points for deducing the basic laws and state functions of thermodynamics more difficult than for instance a treatment based upon Callen's (Callen 1985) approach of which the author suggests (p. 7) that an appeal to molecular concepts is needed. This, Lodge thinks, is not correct; Callen's axioms are purely phenomenological and also acceptable without molecular considerations." Jongschaap replies that, as also noted in a recent paper (Jongschaap and Ottinger 2001), it is remarkable that "...despite the fact that the treatment of common applications such as the calculation of the efficiency of engines, phase behavior, chemical equilibria, etc. are well understood and frequently used, there still seems to be no consensus on the treatment of the fundamentals of thermodynamics." is confirmed again by the issue raised by Professor Lodge's Letter to the Editor about my review of his new book (Lodge 1999)
z:row.User2: internal energy; thermostatics; macroscopic treatment; engine efficiency; phase behavior; chemical equilibria; thermodynamics fundamentals; molecular concepts; basic laws; state functions; thermodynamics; phenomenological axioms

z:row.TitlePrimary: Reflections on “Simple presentation of network theory of rubber, with a discussion of other theories,” Hubert M. James and Eugene Guth, J. Polym. Sci., IV, 153 (1949)
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Polym. Sci. B, Polym. Phys. (USA)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Polymer Science, Part B (Polymer Physics)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Bannatek Co. Inc., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: James and Guth were the first to consider the full molecular network; they restricted their affine displacement assumption to the sample boundary points. They proved that the average positions of network junctions shared the affine motion of the boundary points. They also showed that the network junctions fluctuated about their average positions with amplitudes comparable to those of the rest of the strand points, but that, nevertheless, for some but not all. calculations, it was safe to ignore the junction fluctuations and treat the junctions as if they were located at their ensemble-averaged positions. They also abandoned-the early theories' incompressibility assumption; to represent the combined effects of all the secondary force interactions between molecules, they simply added to the Helmholtz free energy a function of density and temperature alone
z:row.User2: network theory; rubber; full molecular network; affine displacement assumption; sample boundary points; average positions; network junctions; affine motion; strand points; junction fluctuations; ensemble-averaged positions; incompressibility assumption; secondary force interactions; Helmholtz free energy; density; temperature

z:row.TitlePrimary: On-line measurement of elasticity and viscosity in flowing polymeric liquids
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Bannatek Co., Inc., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A new slit-die rheometer (the Stressmeter) for on-line and sample measurement of the viscosity, η, and the first normal stress difference, N1, in steady shear flow for molten polymers and other high-viscosity liquids is described. Two liquid-filled transverse slots, located in one die wall near the center station, give pressures P2 and P3 from whose difference the wall shear stress σ is calculated. In the other die wall at a location opposite the center of the P2 slot is a flush-mounted transducer, giving a pressure P1. N1 is calculated from the hole pressure P*=P1-P2. A metering pump, used to measure the flow rate Q, is supplied with melt either from an extruder (on-line mode) or from a pressurized sample cylinder (sample mode). The wall shear rate γ is calculated from Q and σ; the Weissenberg-Rabinowitsch correction and a new small-viscous-heating-correction algorithm (affecting σ) are used. Viscous heating corrections are small; entrance and exit errors are negligible. The instrument is tested by comparing its results with those obtained from cone-plate and capillary rheometers. Measurement ranges extend to σ=200 kPa, γ=3000 s-1, and temperature=250°C
z:row.User2: polymeric liquids; slit die rheometer; online measurement; elasticity; viscosity; first normal stress difference; steady shear flow; molten polymers; liquid filled transverse slots; shear stress; hole pressure; flow rate; wall shear rate; Weissenberg Rabinowitsch correction; correction algorithm; viscous heating corrections; 150 to 250 C

z:row.TitlePrimary: Viscous heating correction for thermally developing flows in slit die viscometry
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Eng. Mech., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In the thermally developing region, dπyy/dx|y=h varies along the flow direction x, where πyy denotes the component of stress normal to the y-plane; y=±h at the die walls. A finite element method for two-dimensional Newtonian flow in a parallel slit was used to obtain an equation relating dπyy/dx|y=h and the wall shear stress σw0 at the inlet; isothermal slit walls were used for the calculation and the inlet liquid temperature T0 was assumed to be equal to the wall temperature. For a temperature-viscosity relation η/η0 a simple expression was found to hold over the practical range of parameters involved. An order-of-magnitude analysis for momentum and energy equations supports the validity of this expression
z:row.User2: momentum equations; viscous heating correction; thermally developing flows; slit die viscometry; finite element method; two-dimensional Newtonian flow; parallel slit; shear stress; isothermal slit walls; temperature-viscosity relation; energy equations

z:row.TitlePrimary: Hole-pressure problem
z:row.Keyword: Flow of Fluids -- Newtonian|Stresses|Mathematical Techniques - Numerical Analysis
z:row.PeriodicalFull: IMA Journal of Applied Mathematics (Institute of Mathematics & Its Applications)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin at Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The steady flow of a Newtonian fluid between two parallel planes separated by a distance h is considered. The slot runs transversely to the direction of the fluid motion. The mathematical and experimental problem is to determine the difference between the normal stress acting on the bottom of the slot and that acting on the upper wall above the opening to the slot, a quantity often referred to as the hole pressure. In this paper, some of the properties of the flow are examined, and, on the basis of computations, a standard calculation is proposed, where the hole pressure is determined as a function of the Reynolds number in the special case of a square hole with b = d = 1. Some comparisons are made between different computations of the hole pressure, and comparisons are also given, for the case of extremely deep holes, between computed values of the hole pressure and experimental measurements.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Navier-Stokes Equation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements of N1 - N2 and η in steady shear flow and η prime , η double prime , and birefringence in small-strain oscillatory shear for the polyisobutylene solution M1
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of an International Conference on Extensional Flow, Mar 20-23 1989
z:row.Keyword: Fluids -- Solutions|Flow of Fluids - Non Newtonian|Stresses - Shear|Polymers - Decomposition
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Combloux, Fr
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison Rheology Research Cent and Dep of Chemical Engineering, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Steady shear flow Stressmeter data for N1 - N2 and shear stress σ near 20 ° C for increasing and decreasing values of shear rate @@ in the range 14-427 s-1 exhibit hysteresis and evidence of polymer degradation; N1 and N2 denote the first and second normal stress differences in steady shear flow. Comparison with BASF cone-plate data for N1 shows that N2/N1 lies in the range from -0.1 to -0.2. Values of η prime at temperatures in the range 0-40°C and values of angular frequency ω in the range 1-3600 s-1, obtained with a coaxial cylinder rheometer in which the inner cylinder oscillates along its axis, give satisfactory time-temperature superposition; values of η double prime , however, show small but significant deviations from time-temperature superposition. Additional aspects of the study are discussed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Shear Flow; Birefringence; Oscillatory Shear; Polyisobutylene; Shear Flow

z:row.TitlePrimary: Slit die viscometry at shear rates up to 5×106 s-1: an analytical correction for small viscous heating errors
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Considers viscous heating effects on flows through a slit die. The authors assume that stress, velocity, and temperature fields are fully developed at the die center and that the effect of pressure on viscosity is negligible. The variation of viscosity with temperature and shear rate is considered. The authors find that the effects of viscous heating on velocity and temperature profiles for slit dies differ significantly from those for capillary flow
z:row.User2: slit die viscometry; stress fields; velocity fields; shear rates; analytical correction; small viscous heating errors; viscous heating effects; slit die; temperature fields; shear rate

z:row.TitlePrimary: Elastic recovery and polymer-polymer interactions
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Eng. Mech., Wisconsin Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Elastic recovery in polymeric liquids is a cooperative phenomenon in the sense that individual polymer molecules undergoing retraction must interact with one another in order to generate recovery. Stress generated by polymer molecules under an externally imposed flow field may or may not be a cooperative phenomenon. The author suggests that the ability to describe the large elastic recovery exhibited by many polymeric liquids furnishes a crucial test of the validity of methods used to model the interaction of a given polymer molecule with its neighbors. Temporary-junction network models appear to be capable of explaining observed recoveries. A Gaussian network theory equation for the change of volume with elongation for a cross-linked elastomer is generalized in order to allow the bulk compliance to depend on elongation. It is proved that two classes of flow history, namely shear-free and shear, are `constitutively independent' in the sense that, for a given viscoelastic liquid of unknown constitutive equation, the behavior in one class cannot be predicted from rheological measurements (however extensive) made solely in the other class
z:row.User2: elastic recovery; temporary-junction network models; nonNewtonian flow; polymer-polymer interactions; cooperative phenomenon; retraction; recovery; externally imposed flow field; Gaussian network theory equation; elongation; cross-linked elastomer; bulk compliance; elongation; flow history; viscoelastic liquid; constitutive equation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Attempt to measure the first normal-stress difference N1 in shear flow for polyisobuytlene/decalin solution 'D2b' at shear rates up to 106s-1
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: For a polyisobutylene/decalin solution 'D2b,' agreement over a range of values of shear rate γ up to 29,000 s-1 (where the stress ratio N1/σ = 5; σ = shear stress) is found between values of N1 measured near 20°C using a Torsional Balance Rheometer ('TBR') and a 'Stressmeter' ('SM', a slit-die rheometer using transverse slots to measure hole pressures); viscosity values also agree. Time-temperature superposition behavior exhibited by SM data taken in a temperature range 22-99°C suggest that the range of validity of the SM method for determining N1 approximately extends up to γ = 1.3 × 106 s-1; here, N1/σ = 10 and, in the SM die, the Reynolds number Re = 100. This γ value is four times higher than the greatest γ value used in previous similar tests of the SM method made with a similar but more concentrated solution 'D2'.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Shear Flow; Newtonian Liquids; Stressmeter; Viscoelastic Liquids; Polyisobutylene/Decalin Solution

z:row.TitlePrimary: Constitutive equation or stress calculator?
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Eng. Mech., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Various molecular theories of dilute polymer solutions use models in which bead-rod or bead-spring systems immersed in an incompressible Newtonian solvent are subject to thermal motion forces. In order to explain elastic recovery of polymeric liquids in molecular terms, it is essential to specify, not only the retraction mechanism of individual polymer molecules but also the way in which these molecules affect their environment. In the Rouse theory, the actual environment of a given polymer molecule is treated by means of a `mean field' type of assumption, namely that the system of solvent molecules can be replaced by an incompressible Newtonian liquid whose velocity field is restricted. It appears to be typical of this and certain other `mean field' theories that attention is focused on representing the effects of the environment on a given polymer molecule. Such treatments may give `stress calculator' rather than `constitutive' equations, and that if one wishes to calculate free recovery on a molecular basis, it may not be sufficient to put the extra stress zero in `stress calculator' equations
z:row.User2: constitutive equation; bead-rod systems; stress calculator; molecular theories; dilute polymer solutions; models; bead-spring systems; incompressible Newtonian solvent; thermal motion forces; elastic recovery; retraction mechanism; individual polymer molecules; environment; Rouse theory; solvent molecules; velocity field; free recovery

z:row.TitlePrimary: The Weissenberg effect at finite rod-rotation speeds
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Chem. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: According to a known heuristic argument, a given polymeric liquid will be expected to exhibit a positive or negative Weissenberg effect (i.e. will move up or down a rotating vertical rod immersed in it, under conditions where contact angle and centrifugal force effects are negligible) if the value of R:=1+2(σ/N1)dN2/dσ is positive or negative, where σ, N1, and N2 denote the shear stress and first and second normal stress differences in steady shear flow. The value of this heuristic treatment lies in its applicability to finite shear rate ranges for which an exact calculation is not available. The treatment includes (and generalizes) a known exact low-shear-rate limiting condition β00 denotes the low-shear-rate limiting value of β:=-N2/N1. Using published experimental data for N1(σ) and N2(σ) to evaluate R, the authors find that positive Weissenberg effects are predicted for polyisobutylene and some polystyrene solutions (even when β=0.6), in agreement with observation, but that negative effects are predicted for other polystyrene solutions, in disagreement with observation. The authors cannot explain this disagreement. They also use the Curtiss-Bird kinetic theory for monodisperse polymers to evaluate R for various values of the `link tension coefficient' ε. Over ranges of shear rate experimentally accessible for molten polymers, they find that R>0 provided that ε>1/8. When ε=0, however, the authors find that RMω=2Mn, the authors find R values greater than those found for monodisperse polymers. Inertial forces, neglected in the present treatment, could readily be included if required for application to low-viscosity liquids
z:row.User2: link tension coefficient; nonNewtonian flow; Weissenberg effect; finite rod-rotation speeds; polymeric liquid; contact angle; centrifugal force effects; shear stress; stress differences; steady shear flow; heuristic treatment; finite shear rate ranges; rod climbing; polyisobutylene; polystyrene solutions; Curtiss-Bird kinetic theory; monodisperse polymers; molten polymers; Doi-Edwards theory; polydisperse polymers; log-normal distribution

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurement of the first normal-stress difference at high shear rates for a polyisobutylene/decalin solution `D2'
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Eng. Mech., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Reasonable agreement is found between values of the first normal-stress difference N1 for samples of `D2', a polyisobutylene/decalin solution, measured in steady shear flow using three different instruments: a Weissenberg Rheogoniometer (a cone-plate rotational rheometer), a torsional balance (plate-plate rotational) rheometer, and a Stressmeter (a transverse-slot slit-die rheometer). Viscosity values are also in reasonable agreement. Ranges of variables common to at least two rheometers include values of shear stress σ up to 3700 Pa and shear rate γ˙ up to 20700 s-1 near 25°C. The agreement supports the approximate validity of the semi-empirical `HPBL equation' used to calculate N1 from Stressmeter data over a range of shear rates up to 20700 s-1 near 25°C. Time-temperature super-position behavior exhibited by Stressmeter data at temperatures in the range 21°C to 111°C suggest that the range of validity of the Stressmeter method for determining N1 approximately may extend up to shear rates of 290000 s-1 at 111°C
z:row.User2: viscosity; torsional balance rheometer; polyisobutylene; decalin solution; first normal-stress difference; high shear rates; steady shear flow; Weissenberg Rheogoniometer; cone-plate rotational rheometer; Stressmeter

z:row.TitlePrimary: A comment on `On the corotating frame and evolution equations in kinetic theory' [and reply]
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Eng. Mech., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Lodge et al. discuss Eu's consideration of constitutive equations for polymeric liquids (ibid., vol.82, no.8, p.3773, 1985). They claim that certain statements in that work are misleading or incorrect. Their comments were shown to Eu in a first draft. They discuss Eu's response to those comments. Eu replies to their comments on his original work and to their criticism of his response to their first draft
z:row.User2: corotating frame; evolution equations; kinetic theory; constitutive equations; polymeric liquids

z:row.TitlePrimary: RHEODILATOMETER FOR MOLTEN POLYMERS
z:row.Keyword: RHEOMETERS -- Reliability|POLYMERS - Viscosity|DILATOMETERS - Errors|STRESSES - Shear|MECHANICAL VARIABLES MEASUREMENT - Torques
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Rheology Research Cent, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A new cone-plate rheometer has been constructed in order to measure torque-induced sample volume change as well as the usually measured total thrust F and torque M. Of particular importance for molten polymers are the time-dependent values generated by step shear strain or by step shear rate tests: the former when combined with shear stress data, can be used to eliminate infinite classes of otherwise a priori admissible constitutive equations. The evidence suggests that Lin's torque data are anomalous, as he himself believed. One possible explanation for the anomaly that should be considered arises from the unwanted coupling between thrust and torque signals which sometimes occurs with the Rheometrics System Four rheometer.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: RHEODILATOMETER; MOLTEN POLYMERS; CONE PLATE RHEOMETER; TORQUE INDUCED VOLUME CHANGE

z:row.TitlePrimary: A rheodilatometer for molten polymers
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Rheology Res. Center, Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A new cone-plate rheometer has been constructed in order to measure torque-induced sample volume change ΔVs as well as the usually measured total thrust F and torque M. The aim is to use ΔVs data to assess the accuracy of time-dependent values N1(t) of the first normal stress difference calculated from F data obtained in step shear and step shear rate experiments. The cone-plate gap has an 8° angle and 25.4 mm radius. The total axial stiffness is 31.4 MN/m (when F is 100 N); F resolution is about 1 N. ΔVs resolution is about 0.001% at 130°C; a silicone liquid is used as a dilatometer indicator. First applications made with a low-density polyethylene sample (`IUPAC A') at 130°C subjected to a step shear rate of 1 s-1 for a duration of 14 s gave no detectable change in sample volume
z:row.User2: molten polymers; cone-plate rheometer; torque-induced sample volume change; time-dependent values; normal stress difference; step shear rate experiments; cone-plate gap; total axial stiffness; silicone liquid; low-density polyethylene

z:row.TitlePrimary: CLASSIFICATION OF CONSTITUTIVE EQUATIONS BASED ON STRESS RELAXATION PREDICTIONS FOR THE SINGLE-JUMP SHEAR STRAIN EXPERIMENT
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Engineering Mechanics, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: A classification of constitutive equations for viscoelastic materials is proposed based on the values of the stress ratio of the first normal stress difference to the shear stress following a single jump shear strain in a material otherwise having a constant body metric tensor. Simple examples of hypothetical equations in each class are listed, and some of the published constitutive equations are classified. Limited available experimental data on polymeric liquids favors one class. An Appendix summarizes the definition and main results for body tensors.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Newtonian liquid hole pressures at small Reynolds numbers
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Engng. Mech., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Considers shear flow of a liquid between parallel walls (at separation h). One wall contains a hole whose cross section can be either a circle (of diameter b) or a transverse slot (of narrow dimension b parallel to the main flow direction). There is no net flow though the hole. A transducer at the base of the hole records a pressure P2. A transducer mounted flush with the wall face opposite the hole records a pressure P1 at a location on the hole centerline (produced). Current research interest concerns the relation between the `hole plasma' P*=P1-P2 and N1 and N2, the first and second normal stress differences in steady shear flow. Values for P* have summarised values of Reynolds number Re=ρbhs˙2/4σ less than 10 (ρ=density; s˙ and σ denote wall values of shear rate and shear stress at locations remote from the hole perturbation). At these low Reynolds numbers, P* is approximately proportional to the product Reσ
z:row.User2: Newtonian liquid hole pressures; small Reynolds numbers; shear flow; liquid; parallel walls

z:row.TitlePrimary: Positive hole pressures and negative exit pressures generated by molten polyethylene flowing through a slit die
z:row.Keyword: elasticity of liquids|non-Newtonian flow|polymer melts|rheology|shear flow|viscosity of liquids
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Rheology Res. Center, Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A new slit die rheometer has been constructed to measure elastic and viscous properties of molten polymers at low shear rates. The wall shear stress σ and the extrapolated exit pressure Px are determined by means of two pressure transducers mounted flush with a die wall. The hole pressure P* is obtained from one of the flush-mounted transducers and a third transducer mounted in a transverse slot opposite the flush-mounted transducer. The wall shear rate s˙ is obtained from a metering pump. Electrical heaters give melt temperatures that are uniform to within ±0.1°C at 150°C. For two low-density polyethylene samples of Melt Index 2 and 50, at shear rates in the range 0.1 to 8 s-1, it is found that (a) viscosity values agree with those obtained using two Weissenberg Rheogoniometers (WRGs); (b) hole pressure data agree with the predictions of the `HPB' transverse-slot equation N1=2δdP*/dσ when WRG data are used for the first normal stress difference N1; and (c) exit pressures are large and negative, in marked disagreement with certain published equations relating Px, N1 and σ. An error analysis shows that Px values can contain significant negative contributions arising from the pressure dependence of viscosity, even at low shear rates. As a means for in-line measurement of melt elasticity at low shear rates, the results favor the use of the hole pressure, but raise serious questions about the use of the exit pressure
z:row.User2: elastic properties; positive hole pressures; slit die rheometer; viscous properties; molten polymers; shear rates; wall shear stress; pressure transducers; hole pressure; flush-mounted transducers; wall shear rate; melt temperatures; low-density polyethylene samples; Weissenberg Rheogoniometers; error analysis; pressure dependence; viscosity; elasticity; shear rates

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the measurement of normal stress differences in steady shear flow. IV. A new truncated-cone plate (`TCP') apparatus
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Engng. Res. Building, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Compared to the similar pressure-distribution cone-and-plate apparatus of Adams and Lodge, (1964), the new apparatus' improvements include: temperature control of the cone (as well as the plate); increased stiffening of the frame; four (not three) pressure-measuring holes in the cone/plate region; inclusion of a pressure-measuring hole on the axis under the cone truncation; exclusive use of a vertical free liquid boundary at the cone rim (without a `sea' of liquid). Temperature control of the rotating cone and of the fixed plate leads to acceptable temperature uniformity in the test liquid for working temperatures within 10°C and 20°C of ambient; the corresponding interval is about 1°C if the cone temperature control is abandoned. Pressure gradients measured using a Newtonian liquid agree with those calculated using Walters' equation (1975). For a viscoelastic liquid, after subtracting inertial contributions, pressure distributions measured at a given shear rate in the cone/plate region do not change when the gap angle is changed from 2° to 3°, showing that the effects of secondary flow are negligible
z:row.User2: truncated cone and plate measurements; vertical free liquid boundary; cone temperature control; Newtonian liquid; viscoelastic liquid; pressure distributions; shear rate; gap angle

z:row.TitlePrimary: Hole pressure error measurements in pressure-generated shear flow
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the Society of Rheology
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin-Madison Rheology Res. Centre, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A slit-die apparatus is described and used to determine the hole pressure error PH in pressure-generated shear flow of viscoelastic liquids. Measurements are made on three aqueous solutions of polyacrylamide. Stress states have been determined from wall pressure measurements. It is concluded that hole pressure errors may be safely ignored in shear stress determinations, but not in the determination of normal stress differences
z:row.User2: hole pressure error; shear flow; viscoelastic liquids; aqueous solutions; wall pressure measurements; shear stress; normal stress; fluid dynamics instrumentation; nonNewtonian flow; slit die apparatus

z:row.TitlePrimary: Comparison of network theory predictions with stress/time data in shear and elongation for a low-density polyethylene melt
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experimental data are presented which show the variation with time of the shear stress and primary normal stress difference during shear flow with a step- function shear rate; the material is a low-density polyethylene melt for which stress-growth and elastic recovery data in elongational flow experiments have been previously reported. A method of comparing the data with the predictions of the rubber-like-liquid constitutive equations is given, based on the use of a specially-chosen rate-of-strain invariant. From this comparison, it is shown that the disagreement between theory and experiment is about the same for shear flow and for elongational flow, and that the extent of disagreement does not exceed 10% for short-duration flows such that IIVt⩽3
z:row.User2: network theory predictions; shear; elongation; polyethylene melt; shear flow; shear stress; primary normal stress difference; shear rate; elastic recovery; elongational flow; constitutive equations; stress time data; stress growth; rate of strain invariant

z:row.TitlePrimary: NONLINEAR ELASTIC PROPERTIES OF MOLTEN PLASTICS
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Body tensor fields are defined and their advantages in describing the properties of viscoelastic materials, subjected to arbitrary strain histories, are summarized. The left double quote rubberlike liquid right double quote constitutive equation, based on a molecular network theory for polymeric liquids, is stated, and is used to derive a nonlinear Volterra integral equation whose solution gives free recovery following elongational flow at constant elongation rate. Solutions computed by Hui Chang are compared with data for ultimate free recovery obtained by Meissner in experiments with a molten low-density polyethylene for which stress growth data in shear and in elongation had also been obtained.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: POLYMER RHEOLOGY

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the description of rheological properties of viscoelastic continua. I. Body-, space-, and Cartesian-space-tensor fields
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A method of defining tensor fields associated with a given continuum is presented and applied to the description of rheological variables for a continuous material moving and deforming in space. Three different types of tensor field are defined and compared: body fields, space fields, and Cartesian space fields. A bold-face notation is introduced for body tensor fields and its relation to other authors' notations for space fields is presented. Body fields give the simplest description of rheological states because body stress and body metric tensor fields, unlike space stress and strain tensor fields, are independent of the orientation of material elements relative to directions fixed in space
z:row.User2: rheological properties; viscoelastic continua; tensor fields; body fields; space fields; Cartesian space fields; body stress

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the description of rheological properties of viscoelastic continua. II. Proof that Oldroyd's 1950 formalism includes all `simple fluids'
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: For pt I see Ibid., vol 11, 106 (1972). It is proved that the following two classes of idealized incompressible materials are identical: (i) materials for which the Cartesian extra-stress tensor is expressible as a one-particle functional of the Cartesian deformation gradient tensor subject to a `material objectivity' condition; (ii) materials for which the contravariant body extra-stress tensor is expressible as an isotropic one-particle functional of the covariant body metric tensor. From the close relationship of the body tensor formalism (ii) to the convected-component formalism of Oldroyd, it follows that all `Simple Fluids' (i) are included in Oldroyd's formalism
z:row.User2: rheological properties; viscoelastic continua; body tensor formalism; Oldroyd's formalism

z:row.TitlePrimary: Comparison of rubberlike-liquid theory with stress-growth data for elongation of a low-density branched polyethylene melt
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The non-linear behavior observed by Meissner can be qualitatively described by the rubberlike-liquid constitutive equations when the constants in the memory function are chosen to fit the data in the linear region at low elongation rates
